awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Isotopic Reflections of Mobility and Labor Patterns
awd_abstract_narration:
Candice Ralston, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of California-Davis, will conduct archaeometric research to study the relationship between social organization and the division of labor for hunter-gatherer populations. Place of residence after marriage, or postmarital residence, impacts the structure of societies and their kinship networks. Ralston's dissertation research will investigate the relationship between the relative importance of male versus female contributions to subsistence and diet, and postmarital residence. Advancements in stable isotope analysis of human skeletal tissues, permit archaeologists to generate nuanced data-sets with which to investigate ancient diet and mobility. Stable isotope analysis provides more direct evidence of paleomigration and diet for individuals, can distinguish individual-level residential and dietary patterns, and permit comparison between male- and female-mobility and dietary patterns. This study uses five isotopic discriminants (strontium, oxygen, sulfur, carbon, and nitrogen). Incorporating multiple lines of isotopic evidence enhances the interpretive power of these analyses for understanding human mobility and the food webs they exploit. This project will also further Ralston's academic and intellectual development.

Evidence will come from two California Central Valley archaeological sites, CA-SAC-107 and CA-SJO-68, dating to the Early Period (ca. 5000-2500 BP).  The California archaeological record shows temporal trends for 1) shifting subsistence-economies and 2) increasing differentiation of gendered labor. As such, the region is ideal to test how subsistence and labor co-vary with postmarital residence. Archaeological research conducted in California's Central Valley has traditionally focused on resource intensification, demographic forcing, and resource depression as drivers of cultural change. By contrast, the dynamics of cultural development and social organization have not been adequately addressed. Cross-cultural analyses suggest that economic systems, the division of labor between women and men, warfare, and territoriality are significant predictors of postmarital residence practices. These findings set up the central question of Ralston's research. Does the division of labor, and more specifically, a biased subsistence contribution to the overall diet, influence postmarital residence for Early Period populations in the Central Valley of California? Ralston will address the research question by 1) reconstructing marital mobility using isotope chemistry (strontium, oxygen, and sulfur) in skeletal tissues to ascertain postmarital residence, 2) interpreting subsistence practices using previously published faunal, botanical, and artifactual data from CA-SAC-107 and CA-SJO-68, and 3) reconstructing the diet of burial populations from the two sites using stable isotopes of carbon and nitrogen in bone collagen, and carbon in bioapatite. Ralston's dissertation research will clarify synchronic patterns of postmarital residence for the Early Period but also, when combined with site-specific data from different periods, provide a diachronic perspective that will elucidate the evolution of postmarital residence practices of indigenous groups of California and, more broadly, hunter-gatherers. Additionally, this study will demonstrate the significance of using multi-isotopic approaches to understanding ancient human behavior.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Candice Ralston (Co-PI), with funds awarded from the NSF DDIG, conducted archaeometric analyses to study the relationship between social organization and the sexual division of labor for hunter-gatherer populations. Her Ph.D. dissertation reports and interprets results from these analyses and was filed and accepted in December 2021 at the University of California, Davis. Ralston's research is influenced by early anthropological and social theories, which suggest that the sexual division of labor correlates to postmarital residence patterns. Those studies hypothesized that matridominant subsistence favors matrilocality while patridominant subsistence favors patrilocality. Stable isotope analysis provides evidence of paleomigration and diet for individuals, can distinguish between site- and individual-level residential and dietary patterns, and permits comparison between male- and female-mobility and dietary patterns.

This project uses five isotopic discriminants (strontium [87Sr/86Sr], oxygen [δ18O], sulfur [δ34S], carbon [δ13C], and nitrogen [δ15N]). Evidence comes from two California Central Valley burial populations from archaeological sites, CA-SAC-107 and CA-SJO-68, dating to the Early Period (ca. 5000-2500 BP). Human remains used in this study are culturally unaffiliated and are curated at the Phoebe A. Hearst Museum of Anthropology (PAHMA). The PAHMA granted permission to collect samples from ten females and six males from SAC-107, and 12 females and 15 males from SJO-68.

Ralston's central research question ―Does sexual division of labor, and more specifically, sex-biased subsistence contribution to the overall diet, influence postmarital residence for Early Period populations in the Central Valley of California?― was addressed in three ways:

1) Reconstructing sex-biased mobility using isotope chemistry (87Sr/86Sr, δ18O, and δ34S) in skeletal tissues to ascertain postmarital residence.

2) Interpreting subsistence practices using previously published faunal, botanical, and artifactual data.

3) Reconstructing the diet using δ13C and δ15N of bone collagen, and δ13C of bioapatite.

Additionally, Ralston conducted radiocarbon dating (SAC-107 = 14; SJO-68 = 44) to confirm temporal affiliation. Radiocarbon assays range from 4497+/-27 to 3132+/-24 RCYBP at SJO-68, and 3427+/-26 to 135+/-20 RCYBP at SAC-107. While originally the study focused on the Early Period, these surprising radiocarbon results from SAC-107 necessitated a re-evaluation of chronological patterns.

Paleodietary reconstruction using δ13C and δ15N of human bone collagen and δ13C of bone apatite largely support expectations from archaeofaunal, paleobotanical, and artifactual evidence from central California. Isotopic indicators reveal that the SAC-107 population foraged within a C3-terrestrial food web with minimal sex differences. Confounding variables, including small sample sizes and the temporal bias of sampled elements, limited interpretation of sex-biased mobility and postmarital residence in the Early Period using δ34S, δ18O, and 87Sr/86Sr at SAC-107. However, isotopic results relating to human geolocation are generally consistent with marriage endogamy and increasing sedentism over time.

Paleodietary reconstruction at SJO-68 using δ13C and δ15N of human bone is consistent with a high input of freshwater-riverine resources and demonstrates that males typically consumed higher-trophic-level resources than females. Results of paleomobility analysis and interpretation of postmarital residence using δ34S, δ18O, and 87Sr/86Sr at SJO-68 are consistent with endogamous marriage practices and greater mobility for males, particularly during late adolescence.

This project illustrates how archaeological data is a valuable source of empirical evidence to test anthropological theory. Conventionally, the development of anthropological theories and the testing of hypotheses derived from those theories relied on ethnographic data from societies that typically lived between the 18th and mid-20th centuries. This project demonstrates how archaeometric techniques produce individual-level data from which ancient human behaviors can be gleaned (e.g., sex-biased mobility patterns) and how this data expands the temporal range of subjects available to analyze broader anthropological theories. In particular, this project generated data useful for evaluating and interpreting postmarital residence patterns for populations who lived as early as ~5,000 years ago. Additionally, this project analyzes archaeological materials excavated in the 1930s-1950s. Work with these collections exemplifies the importance of archaeologists seeking extant, legacy collections recovered from cultural resource management and salvage projects that have largely been ignored and highlighting the importance of undertaking new analyses of previously excavated materials.

Several undergraduate students from the University of California, Berkeley and early-career archaeologists obtained experience in osteology, scientific sampling, and working with archaeological collections by assisting in sample selection, extraction, and recording at the PAHMA. In addition, undergraduate students working in the Archaeometry Laboratory at the University of California, Davis gained experience processing samples for isotopic studies and working in a scientific laboratory setting.

This study's dietary isotope results were shared with interested public members through a webinar presented to the Sacramento Archaeological Society in June 2020. A subset of the δ34S results used to interpret paleomobility at SJO-68 is published online as part of the Society for California Archaeology Proceedings (2020) and presented at the SCA annual meeting (2021). As well, all results from this study are reported in Ralston's dissertation, which will be made available to the public through ProQuest in 2022.


Last Modified: 03/01/2022
Modified by: Candice Ralston
